titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Ezra Laderman Papers
titlestmt.author: Finding aid compiled by Emily DiLeo, with the assistance of Jacob Fewx and Jane Meditz. Biographical note written by Richard Boursy.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 00:01
profiledesc.descrules: translation missing: en.enumerations.resource_finding_aid_description_rules.Describing Archives: A Content Standard

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Papers are focused principally on Laderman's prolific career as a composer. Virtually all of his compositions are held in the collection, including chamber music, orchestral works, operas and musicals, oratorios and cantatas, and scores for film and television. The collection contains many sketches and drafts, which give insight into Laderman's compositional process. The collection also contains a significant number of reel-to-reel recordings of Laderman's works.

The remainder of the collection consists of correspondence, writings, clippings, programs, documents and awards. The correspondence is divided into three subseries: Correspondence with significant figures; Correspondence by subject; and Correspondence by date. Researchers are advised to consult all three subseries when looking for material on a specific topic. The Writings, Professional Activities and Photographs series contains a range of material related to Laderman's roles as President of the American Academy of Arts and Letters, Chairman of Music Programs the National Endowment for the Arts, and Dean of the Yale School of Music. Researchers should also consult the Correspondence by Subject subseries for correspondence related to Laderman's professional activities.

Clippings, publicity, and programs span the whole of Laderman's career â€“ from the 1940s through 2015. The Documents and awards series includes items such as degree certificates, school report cards, and award plaques.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Ezra Laderman ranks among the leading American composers of his time. Born in Brooklyn in 1924, he was educated at the High School of Music and Art, Brooklyn College, and Columbia University; his teachers included Stefan Wolpe, Miriam Gideon, Otto Luening, and Douglas Moore. Service in the U.S. Army during World War II interrupted his formal education, but not his compositional career; after participating in the liberation of Leipzig, he wrote a symphony inspired by the experience.

Laderman was a prolific composer in a range of genres; he produced numerous symphonies, concertos, and chamber works, and he created operas based on characters as varied as Galileo Galilei and Marilyn Monroe. His music has been performed by many leading ensembles and soloists, including the New York Philharmonic, the Chicago Symphony, the Philadelphia Orchestra, Yo-Yo Ma, Emanuel Ax, Elmar Oliveira, and Jean-Pierre Rampal. His musical career spanned several eras; he began composing as a boy in the 1930s, and he continued nearly until his death in 2015.

Laderman was an educator and administrator as well as a composer. He taught at several institutions, most notably the Yale School of Music, where he served as Dean and as Professor of Composition. He was Chairman of Music Programs at the National Endowment for the Arts, and President of the American Academy of Arts and Letters, the American Music Center, and the National Music Council.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Duplicates of manuscript scores, and published, ummarked scores have been separated from the collection.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Papers are divided into seven series: I. Music; II. Audiovisual material; III. Correspondence; IV. Writings and professional activities; V. Clippings and publicity; VI. Programs; and VII. Documents and awards. The Papers were received in several installments over a period of thirty years. The collection was partially processed in the 1990s, which influenced its current arrangement.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes a wide variety of formats: pencil sketches, pencil manuscript scores, Ozalid transparencies and copies, annotated photocopies, and computer printouts.
Many of the scores include yellow sticky notes with identifying information. These were written by Ezra Laderman himself. Unidentified pieces and fragments are filed at the end of this series.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Pieces are listed in alphabetical order by title. All versions of each piece (e.g., sketch, manuscript score, printed score with edits) are kept together. In some cases, the number of versions necessitated housing the material in multiple boxes.
Note that listed dates can refer to the date of composition and/or date of publication.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Material in this subseries includes works described by Laderman as "uncompleted", or "abandoned". Two of the pieces are labeled "false starts". Also included are unfinished orchestral versions of other (complete) pieces.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Most of the sketches are not identified. The majority are pencil sketches, although there are some photocopies. Also included are sketch notebooks.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The reel-to-reel tapes are listed by box. Titles are transcribed directly from the cases.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence sent and received by Ezra Laderman. The series is divided into three subseries: 1. Correspondence with significant individuals; 2. Correspondence by subject - which includes organizations, specific individuals, and correspondence concerning specific pieces Laderman composed; and 3. Correspondence by date.

did.unittitle: Violin Concerto, Organ Preludes, Piano Trio
A Single Voice and Various Shorter Works
Momente, From The Psalms, 5 Trios and a Fanfare, Duo for Violin and Piano
Satine, Duo for Flute and Dancer

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes newspaper articles, music reviews, school assigments, speeches, interviews, scripts, and autobiographical material.

did.unittitle: American Academy of Arts and Letters material

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes newspaper articles, correspondence, membership information, and Laderman's presidential address.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Material from Laderman's time as a member of the National Endowment for the Arts. Includes NEA guidelines, meeting agendas, grant proposals (both approved and rejected), correspondence, and other financial information.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Also includes composer librettist translator program grant applications, 1975.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes material related to various institutions for whom Laderman acted as judge for music competitions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials related to Laderman's professorship at the Yale School of Music, including programs, documents, course materials, and brochures from Yale alumni tours which Laderman attended as a professor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs consist of professional headshots, Laderman composing and conducting, and Laderman with colleagues and students. Also included are photos from ASCAP and the American Academy of Arts and Letters.

did.unittitle: Drafts of letters, miscellaneous notes, addresses and invitations

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series consists of loose newspaper and magazine clippings related to Laderman's music. Also included are two albums, one containing clippings related to "Marilyn", and the other from the 1960s. Note that posters for The Hunting of the Snark and The Eleanor Roosevelt Story are housed in Box 93.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The bulk of this series consists of programs from performances of Laderman's music. Also included are handwritten and typewritten program notes, most of which were written by Laderman himself. The final two subseries contain programs from concerts which do not include Laderman's music (presumably concerts Laderman attended), and programs for non-music events such as graduation ceremonies and dinners.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes program notes for various pieces, most of which written by Laderman himself.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Press release information regarding important performances of Laderman's music.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes various programs which do not include Laderman music.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes commencement and ceremonial event programs, schedules for lectures given by Laderman, and music magazines.

did.unittitle: Passports, ASCAP membership certificate and union membership cards
Parents' Association Award for Excellence in Theory and Composition (High School of Music and Art, 1941)
The National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences Award for Outstanding Achievement in Cultural Documentaries: Galileo (1967-68)
National Guild of Community Schools of the Arts New York Metropolitan Chapter, Distinguished Alumnus Award For Outstanding Services to the Arts (1986)
In Recognition of Outstanding Contributions to American Orchestras as a member of The American Symphony Orchestra League Board of Directors 1987-1992
